response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this measure is to appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and to establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund to assist the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation in facilitating the development of mixed-income rental housing projects (HB431_HD1). This measure represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawaii's most vulnerable populations by providing additional funds for these initiatives (HB431_HD1). It also aims to support partnerships between government and the community to create an effective, efficient, and transparent system for developers, service providers, and individuals with special housing needs (HB431_HD1).",
  "appropriations": "While the measure was amended to change appropriations to unspecified amounts, the Committee on Human Services & Homelessness respectfully requests the Committee on Finance to consider an appropriation of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative. It also requests consideration of $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) to be deposited into the Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1). Of this amount, $11,810,250 (HB431_HD1) is for financing the development, operation, and maintenance of supportive housing projects and services, and $189,750 (HB431_HD1) is for one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Housing Finance Specialist I position (HB431_HD1).",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The fiscal projections are based on amounts requested for consideration by the House Committee on Finance as detailed in the standing committee report for H.B. No. 431, H.D. 1 (HB431_HD1). The report proposes an appropriation of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1). The cost for the new position is specified as $189,750 (HB431_HD1), but the documents do not provide a detailed breakdown or methodology for how these overall funding levels were determined.",
  "agency_impact": "The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) supports the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help with the administration of the supportive housing special fund (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The State Procurement Office recommends that procurement exemption language be removed, stating that exemptions mean procurements made with taxpayer monies will not have the same oversight, accountability and transparency requirements (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The Department of Budget and Finance does not support the creation of any special fund which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.3, HRS, and notes it is difficult to determine whether the proposed fund would be self-sustaining (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_).",
  "economic_impact": "Testimony from the Office of Hawaiian Affairs indicates that supportive housing has significant economic benefits, citing a finding that people offered supportive housing spent 23% fewer days in hospitals and had 33% fewer emergency room visits (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The same testimony notes that supportive housing reduces recidivism, referencing a study showing the rate for individuals with housing support was 12.8% versus 50% without (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). This suggests the measure could lower cost burdens on public healthcare and incarceration systems.",
  "policy_impact": "This measure establishes the Supportive Housing Special Fund to be administered by the Hawai‘i Housing Finance and Development Corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects (HB431_HD1). A key amendment in this version of the bill was deleting language that would have established a separate Kauhale Initiative Special Fund (HB431_HD1). The committee also inserted language that appropriates an unspecified amount to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative (HB431_HD1).",
  "revenue_sources": "The measure appropriates an unspecified amount of general funds in both FY 26 and FY 27 to the Office of the Governor for the Kauhale Initiative (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). It also appropriates an unspecified amount of general funds in both fiscal years for deposit into the Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The Department of Budget and Finance testimony suggests the fund is not designed to be financially self-sustaining and would rely on these general fund appropriations (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_).",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The measure signals continued significant state investment in homelessness solutions, following a history of substantial appropriations. Previously, the ohana zones pilot program was initially appropriated $30,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt), with subsequent acts providing $2,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt), $15,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt), and $5,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt) for related programs (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt). In 2023, the legislature also appropriated $25,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt) to fund the kauhale initiative (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt). This bill requests consideration of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the new Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1). A recurring administrative cost will be the temporary Housing Finance Specialist I position at a cost of $189,750 (HB431_HD1). Given the ongoing nature of the housing crisis, similar levels of funding requests can be anticipated in subsequent fiscal years to sustain program operations and expand capacity.",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided documents for this version of the bill do not specify any new sources of operating revenue. The Department of Budget and Finance testimony notes that it is \"difficult to determine whether the proposed SHSF would be self-sustaining\" (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_), indicating an expected reliance on general fund appropriations rather than self-generated revenue. Therefore, no direct impact on operating revenue is anticipated from this measure.",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The measure is expected to have a significant impact on capital expenditures, as the Supportive Housing Special Fund is intended for the \"financing of the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects\" (HB431_HD1). Testimony from the County of Hawai‘i Office of Housing and Community Development identifies potential projects, including funding for the second phase of Kukuiola Village for the construction of 50 permanent supportive housing units (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The funds could also assist with the \"renovation and upgrades of the former Hilo Memorial Hospital\" (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_).",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The establishment of the Supportive Housing Special Fund and the continued funding for the Kauhale Initiative imply ongoing fiscal commitments beyond the initial six-year period. These long-term obligations will likely include recurring requests for general fund appropriations to maintain operations, provide supportive services, and develop new housing units. The administrative cost for the HHFDC staff position, while designated as temporary, may become a recurring expense if the program's responsibilities continue.",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This fiscal note differs significantly from the previous version by providing specific requested appropriation amounts instead of unspecified sums. The committee report for H.D. 1 requests consideration of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Supportive Housing Special Fund, with the FTE cost updated to $189,750 (HB431_HD1). A key policy change is the deletion of the previously proposed \"Kauhale Initiative Special Fund\" (HB431_HD1), which is a new development. This note also includes new agency impact information from the Department of Budget and Finance, which expressed concerns about the special fund's ability to be self-sustaining (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_)."
}

parts.text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this measure is to appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and to establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund to assist the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation in facilitating the development of mixed-income rental housing projects (HB431_HD1). This measure represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawaii's most vulnerable populations by providing additional funds for these initiatives (HB431_HD1). It also aims to support partnerships between government and the community to create an effective, efficient, and transparent system for developers, service providers, and individuals with special housing needs (HB431_HD1).",
  "appropriations": "While the measure was amended to change appropriations to unspecified amounts, the Committee on Human Services & Homelessness respectfully requests the Committee on Finance to consider an appropriation of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative. It also requests consideration of $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) to be deposited into the Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1). Of this amount, $11,810,250 (HB431_HD1) is for financing the development, operation, and maintenance of supportive housing projects and services, and $189,750 (HB431_HD1) is for one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Housing Finance Specialist I position (HB431_HD1).",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The fiscal projections are based on amounts requested for consideration by the House Committee on Finance as detailed in the standing committee report for H.B. No. 431, H.D. 1 (HB431_HD1). The report proposes an appropriation of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1). The cost for the new position is specified as $189,750 (HB431_HD1), but the documents do not provide a detailed breakdown or methodology for how these overall funding levels were determined.",
  "agency_impact": "The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) supports the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help with the administration of the supportive housing special fund (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The State Procurement Office recommends that procurement exemption language be removed, stating that exemptions mean procurements made with taxpayer monies will not have the same oversight, accountability and transparency requirements (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The Department of Budget and Finance does not support the creation of any special fund which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.3, HRS, and notes it is difficult to determine whether the proposed fund would be self-sustaining (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_).",
  "economic_impact": "Testimony from the Office of Hawaiian Affairs indicates that supportive housing has significant economic benefits, citing a finding that people offered supportive housing spent 23% fewer days in hospitals and had 33% fewer emergency room visits (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The same testimony notes that supportive housing reduces recidivism, referencing a study showing the rate for individuals with housing support was 12.8% versus 50% without (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). This suggests the measure could lower cost burdens on public healthcare and incarceration systems.",
  "policy_impact": "This measure establishes the Supportive Housing Special Fund to be administered by the Hawai‘i Housing Finance and Development Corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects (HB431_HD1). A key amendment in this version of the bill was deleting language that would have established a separate Kauhale Initiative Special Fund (HB431_HD1). The committee also inserted language that appropriates an unspecified amount to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative (HB431_HD1).",
  "revenue_sources": "The measure appropriates an unspecified amount of general funds in both FY 26 and FY 27 to the Office of the Governor for the Kauhale Initiative (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). It also appropriates an unspecified amount of general funds in both fiscal years for deposit into the Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The Department of Budget and Finance testimony suggests the fund is not designed to be financially self-sustaining and would rely on these general fund appropriations (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_).",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The measure signals continued significant state investment in homelessness solutions, following a history of substantial appropriations. Previously, the ohana zones pilot program was initially appropriated $30,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt), with subsequent acts providing $2,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt), $15,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt), and $5,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt) for related programs (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt). In 2023, the legislature also appropriated $25,000,000 (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt) to fund the kauhale initiative (HB431_HD1_.HTM.txt). This bill requests consideration of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the new Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1). A recurring administrative cost will be the temporary Housing Finance Specialist I position at a cost of $189,750 (HB431_HD1). Given the ongoing nature of the housing crisis, similar levels of funding requests can be anticipated in subsequent fiscal years to sustain program operations and expand capacity.",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided documents for this version of the bill do not specify any new sources of operating revenue. The Department of Budget and Finance testimony notes that it is \"difficult to determine whether the proposed SHSF would be self-sustaining\" (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_), indicating an expected reliance on general fund appropriations rather than self-generated revenue. Therefore, no direct impact on operating revenue is anticipated from this measure.",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The measure is expected to have a significant impact on capital expenditures, as the Supportive Housing Special Fund is intended for the \"financing of the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects\" (HB431_HD1). Testimony from the County of Hawai‘i Office of Housing and Community Development identifies potential projects, including funding for the second phase of Kukuiola Village for the construction of 50 permanent supportive housing units (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_). The funds could also assist with the \"renovation and upgrades of the former Hilo Memorial Hospital\" (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_).",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The establishment of the Supportive Housing Special Fund and the continued funding for the Kauhale Initiative imply ongoing fiscal commitments beyond the initial six-year period. These long-term obligations will likely include recurring requests for general fund appropriations to maintain operations, provide supportive services, and develop new housing units. The administrative cost for the HHFDC staff position, while designated as temporary, may become a recurring expense if the program's responsibilities continue.",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This fiscal note differs significantly from the previous version by providing specific requested appropriation amounts instead of unspecified sums. The committee report for H.D. 1 requests consideration of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) for the Supportive Housing Special Fund, with the FTE cost updated to $189,750 (HB431_HD1). A key policy change is the deletion of the previously proposed \"Kauhale Initiative Special Fund\" (HB431_HD1), which is a new development. This note also includes new agency impact information from the Department of Budget and Finance, which expressed concerns about the special fund's ability to be self-sustaining (HB431_HD1_TESTIMONY_HSG_02-12-25_)."
}

This measure represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawaii's most vulnerable populations by providing additional funds for these initiatives (HB431_HD1)

It also aims to support partnerships between government and the community to create an effective, efficient, and transparent system for developers, service providers, and individuals with special housing needs (HB431_HD1)

",

It also requests consideration of $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1) to be deposited into the Supportive Housing Special Fund (HB431_HD1)

chunk_details.chunk_text: STATE OF HAWAI῾I KA MOKU‘ĀINA O HAWAI‘I STATE COUNCIL ON DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES 'A'UNIKE MOKU'ĀPUNI NO KA NĀ KĀWAI KULA PRINCESS VICTORIA KAMĀMALU BUILDING 1010 RICHARDS STREET, Room 122 HONOLULU, HAWAI῾I 96813 TELEPHONE: (808) 586-8100 FAX: (808) 586-7543 February 12, 2025 The Honorable Representative Luke A. Evslin, Chair House Committee on

The Honorable Representative Luke A. Evslin, Chair House Committee on Housing The Thirty-Third Legislature State Capitol State of Hawai῾i Honolulu, Hawai῾i 96813 Dear Representative Evslin, and Committee Members: SUBJECT: HB431 HD1 Relating to Housing The Hawaii State Council on Developmental Disabilities STRONGLY SUPPORTS HB431 HD1, which appropriates funds for the

Disabilities STRONGLY SUPPORTS HB431 HD1, which appropriates funds for the Kauhale Initiative. Establishes and appropriates funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund. This bill represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawai‘i’s most vulnerable populations, including individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD).

vulnerable populations, including individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD). Hawai‘i’s I/DD population often faces significant barriers to accessing safe, stable, and affordable housing. Individuals with I/DD are more likely to experience unemployment, limited income, and social isolation, making it exceedingly difficult to secure independent housing. HB431 provides a pathway

exceedingly difficult to secure independent housing. HB431 provides a pathway to addressing these systemic challenges by ensuring that housing is affordable and integrated with services necessary for residents to thrive. Supportive services funded under this bill, such as case management, life skills training, and assistance with daily living activities, are

life skills training, and assistance with daily living activities, are vital for individuals with I/DD to live independently and participate fully in their communities. The promotion of mixed-income rental housing developments, as outlined in HB431, fosters inclusive environments where individuals with I/DD can live alongside diverse populations. This approach reduces

with I/DD can live alongside diverse populations. This approach reduces stigma and encourages greater community understanding and acceptance of individuals with disabilities. By addressing housing insecurity and ensuring access to integrated support services, HB431 will enable individuals with I/DD to live more independently and with dignity, reduce HB431HD1 Relating to

live more independently and with dignity, reduce HB431HD1 Relating to Housing February 12, 2025 Page 2 of 2 reliance on costly institutional care or emergency services, and improve overall health, social inclusion, and quality of life for individuals with I/DD. The DD Council believes that the passage of HB431 will

The DD Council believes that the passage of HB431 will have transformative impacts on Hawai‘i’s I/DD community, providing them with the stability and support they need to lead fulfilling and independent lives. We urge you to pass this bill to ensure that the needs of individuals with I/DD and other

ensure that the needs of individuals with I/DD and other vulnerable populations are prioritized in Hawai‘i’s housing solutions. Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony in strong support of HB431 HD1. Sincerely, Daintry Bartoldus Executive Administrator JOSH GREEN, M.D. GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR DEAN MINAKAMI EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR STATE

GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR DEAN MINAKAMI EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND TOURISM HAWAII HOUSING FINANCE AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION 677 QUEEN STREET, SUITE 300 HONOLULU, HAWAII 96813 FAX: (808) 587-0600 Statement of DEAN MINAKAMI Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation Before the HOUSE COMMITTEE

Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation Before the HOUSE COMMITTEE ON HOUSING February 12, 2025 at 9:00 a.m. State Capitol, Room 430 In consideration of H.B. 431 HD1 RELATING TO HOUSING. Chair Evslin, Vice Chair Miyake, and members of the Committee. HHFDC supports HB 431 HD1, which appropriates funds for

Committee. HHFDC supports HB 431 HD1, which appropriates funds for the Kauhale Initiative. It also establishes and appropriates funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund. HHFDC supports the measure so long as it does not adversely impact priorities identified in the Executive Budget Request for FY 2026.

priorities identified in the Executive Budget Request for FY 2026. HHFDC agrees that supportive housing is an innovative solution to house special needs populations, including the chronically homeless, individuals with disabilities, individuals transitioning from incarceration, youth aging out of foster care, domestic violence survivors, veterans, those suffering from substance abuse,

care, domestic violence survivors, veterans, those suffering from substance abuse, and the frail elderly. The Supportive Housing Special Fund is a new financing tool that will help HHFDC to facilitate the development of supportive housing units in standalone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. HHFDC supports the establishment

integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. HHFDC supports the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help with the administration of the supportive housing special fund. Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. STATE OF HAWAI‘I DEPARTMENT OF BUDGET AND FINANCE
this bill. STATE OF HAWAI‘I DEPARTMENT OF BUDGET AND FINANCE Ka ʻOihana Mālama Mo‘ohelu a Kālā P.O. BOX 150 HONOLULU, HAWAI‘I 96810-0150 JOSH GREEN, M.D. LUIS P. SALAVERIA GOVERNOR DIRECT

HSCR3 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 3 Honolulu, Hawaii , 2025 RE: H.B. No. 431 H.D. 1 Honorable Nadine K. Nakamura Speaker, House of Representatives Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Madame: Your Committee on Human Services & Homelessness, to which was referred H.B. No. 431 entitled:

& Homelessness, to which was referred H.B. No. 431 entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative; (2) Establish and appropriate funds into and out

Kauhale Initiative; (2) Establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund to assist the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects; and (3) Establish the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and

Special Fund to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Governor's Coordinator on Homelessness; Department of Human Services; Hawai ‘ i State Council on Developmental Disabilities; Kaua ‘ i County Housing Agency; Catholic Charities Hawai ‘ i; Hawaii

i County Housing Agency; Catholic Charities Hawai ‘ i; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; Democratic Party of Hawai ‘ i; Reimagining Public Safety in Hawai ‘ i Coalition; Hawai ‘ i Health & Harm Reduction Center; Going Home Hawai ‘ i; and three individuals. Your Committee received comments on this measure

and three individuals. Your Committee received comments on this measure from the Department of Budget and Finance. Your Committee finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The State has made significant strides in addressing the pressing issue of homelessness, but continued efforts are needed.

the pressing issue of homelessness, but continued efforts are needed. This measure represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawaii's most vulnerable populations by providing additional funds for the Kauhale Initiative and enabling the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to work with developers to create

Finance and Development Corporation to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. This measure further supports efforts to build partnerships between government and the community, which will help create an effective, efficient, and transparent system for developers, service providers, individuals with special housing needs, and the community as

providers, individuals with special housing needs, and the community as a whole. Your Committee notes that to ensure transparency and fairness within the community, the procurement of services and projects related to the Kauhale Initiative should be awarded, to the extent possible, to multiple bidders and not just a single

extent possible, to multiple bidders and not just a single entity. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts; (2) Deleting language that attempted to prevent the proper lapse of a general fund appropriation at the end of the fiscal biennium for which the

at the end of the fiscal biennium for which the appropriation was made; (3) Deleting language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund; (4) Inserting language that appropriates an unspecified amount to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative; (5) Changing

and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative; (5) Changing the effective dates to June 29, 3000, and July 1, 3000, respectively, to encourage further discussion; and (6) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. Your Committee respectfully requests your Committee on Finance, should it

Your Committee respectfully requests your Committee on Finance, should it deliberate on this measure, to consider an appropriation amount of $50,000,000 for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 to be deposited into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund, including $11,810,250 for the financing of the

Housing Special Fund, including $11,810,250 for the financing of the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services for households with special needs who reside in the supportive housing projects and $189,750 for the establishment and hiring of one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0

the establishment and hiring of one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Housing Finance Specialist I within the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to help with administration of the special fund. As affirmed by the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Human Services & Homelessness that

members of your Committee on Human Services & Homelessness that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 431, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Second Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 431, H.D. 1,

the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 431, H.D. 1, and be referred to your Committee on Housing. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of the Committee on Human Services & Homelessness, ____________________________ LISA MARTEN, Chair

HSCR3 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 3 Honolulu, Hawaii , 2025 RE: H.B. No. 431 H.D. 1 Honorable Nadine K. Nakamura Speaker, House of Representatives Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Madame: Your Committee on Human Services & Homelessness, to which was referred H.B. No. 431 entitled:

& Homelessness, to which was referred H.B. No. 431 entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose of this measure is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative; (2) Establish and appropriate funds into and out

Kauhale Initiative; (2) Establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund to assist the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects; and (3) Establish the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and

Special Fund to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Governor's Coordinator on Homelessness; Department of Human Services; Hawai ‘ i State Council on Developmental Disabilities; Kaua ‘ i County Housing Agency; Catholic Charities Hawai ‘ i; Hawaii

i County Housing Agency; Catholic Charities Hawai ‘ i; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; Democratic Party of Hawai ‘ i; Reimagining Public Safety in Hawai ‘ i Coalition; Hawai ‘ i Health & Harm Reduction Center; Going Home Hawai ‘ i; and three individuals. Your Committee received comments on this measure

and three individuals. Your Committee received comments on this measure from the Department of Budget and Finance. Your Committee finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The State has made significant strides in addressing the pressing issue of homelessness, but continued efforts are needed.

the pressing issue of homelessness, but continued efforts are needed. This measure represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawaii's most vulnerable populations by providing additional funds for the Kauhale Initiative and enabling the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to work with developers to create

Finance and Development Corporation to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. This measure further supports efforts to build partnerships between government and the community, which will help create an effective, efficient, and transparent system for developers, service providers, individuals with special housing needs, and the community as

providers, individuals with special housing needs, and the community as a whole. Your Committee notes that to ensure transparency and fairness within the community, the procurement of services and projects related to the Kauhale Initiative should be awarded, to the extent possible, to multiple bidders and not just a single

extent possible, to multiple bidders and not just a single entity. at the end of the fiscal biennium for which the appropriation was made; (3) Deleting language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund; (4) Inserting language that appropriates an unspecified amount to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative; (5) Changing

and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative; (5) Changing the effective dates to June 29, 3000, and July 1, 3000, respectively, to encourage further discussion; and (6) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. numbers_data.text: 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure

legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the

extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual,

to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless

to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale
